spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: Anaya casts one of the following spells, using Wisdom as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 14}):

spellcasting.name: Divine Aid (3/Day)
headerEntries: Anaya casts {@spell Bless|XPHB}, {@spell Dispel Magic|XPHB}, {@spell Healing Word|XPHB}, or {@spell Lesser Restoration|XPHB}, using the same spellcasting ability as Spellcasting.

action.name: Radiant Flame
entries: {@atkr r} {@hit 6}, range 60 ft. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d10}) Radiant damage.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: Tharian casts one of the following spells, using Wisdom as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 15}, {@hit 7} to hit with spell attacks):

spellcasting.name: Hellish Rebuke
headerEntries: Tharian casts {@spell Hellish Rebuke|XPHB} in response to that spell's trigger, using the same spellcasting ability as Spellcasting.

trait.name: Fiendish Infusion
entries: Attacks and spells that deal Fire damage instead deal Necrotic or Poison damage (his choice).

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Tharian makes three Pact Axe attacks.

action.name: Pact Axe
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 7}, reach 5 ft. {@h}10 ({@damage 1d12 + 4}) Slashing damage plus 13 ({@dice 3d8}) Necroticor Poisondamage.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: Xarashtar casts one of the following spells, requiring no Material components and using Intelligence as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 16}):

trait.name: Demonic Restoration
entries: If Xarashtar dies outside the Abyss, his body dissolves into ichor, and he gains a new body instantly, reviving with all of his {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} somewhere in the Abyss.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: Xarashtar has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Xarashtar makes two Pincer attacks and uses Pummel or Spellcasting.

action.name: Pincer
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 9}, reach 10 ft. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d10 + 5}) Slashing damage. If the target is a Medium or smaller creature, it has the {@condition Grappled|XPHB} condition (escape {@dc 15}) from one of two pincers.

action.name: Pummel
entries: {@actSave dex} {@dc 17}, one creature {@condition Grappled|XPHB} by Xarashtar. {@actSaveFail} 15 ({@damage 3d6 + 5}) Bludgeoning damage. {@actSaveSuccess} Half damage.

{@i Tharian stands taller than before, his shoulders broadened and his once-warm brown eyes darkened. He reaches forward toward you, long claw-like nails protruding from his fingertips as his mouth curves into an inhuman grin.}
{@i As the ichor drips away and the smoke clears, you see a monstrous creature standing 15 feet tall, a canine, fanged head with two jagged horns protruding from its crown.}

data.name: The Malady of Minarrh
entries: {@i An adventure for four to six level 5 characters designed to fill 2 to 3 sessions of play.}

entries.name: Adventure Overview
entries: When a mysterious missive summons the characters to the rural village of Minarrh ({@i mi-NAHR}), they find the town in the clutches of a strange and terrifying malady. Many unafflicted citizens have sequestered themselves in their homes, while the afflicted and their loved ones seek help from the temple healers. {@creature Tharian (Possessed)|MaladyOfMinarrh|Tharian}, the temple leader, shares that his daughter {@creature Anaya|MaladyOfMinarrh}—a gifted healer—was recently kidnapped by the local thieves' guild.

Tharian calls upon the characters to rescue Anaya before the malady consumes the townspeople. However, this small town holds many secrets, from a pair of hidden lovers to the true cause of the malady: an ancient relic unearthed from beneath the temple that contains an imprisoned demon. The demon has been using mind control to make Tharian do his bidding and afflict the town with this malady. Soon, he'll use Tharian and the townspeople's life essence to escape his prison and lay siege to Minarrh and the rest of the Material Plane.

entries.name: Content Warnings
entries: Before running this adventure, discuss the following topics with your players and ensure that each of them is comfortable with these themes appearing in game. You can also adjust the symptoms of the disease and/or ensure that no NPCs die "on screen" to make sure your players are comfortable and everyone is having fun.

entries.name: Horror and Disease
entries: This adventure has horror themes that revolve around a disease caused by a demonic curse. Effects of the disease include hallucinations, involuntary physical transformations, and eventually a gruesome death. As written, the disease can affect player characters, though the adventure's timeline means they won't die from it.

entries.name: NPC Possession and Mind Control
entries: Tharian, one of the main NPCs in the adventure, is mentally influenced—and later posessed by—a demon, who has also magically influenced the minds of several town leaders.

entries.name: Familial Conflict
entries: The adventure also includes a father-daughter relationship which has been complicated by demonic interference, which may be triggering for some players. There are no direct themes of parental neglect or abuse.

entries.name: Adventure Summary
entries: The adventure progresses in three main acts, followed by a final confrontation:

{@area A Mysterious Malady.|00e|x} The party arrives in Minarrh and sees the chaos and suffering caused by the malady. They talk to Tharian, and have a chance to explore {@area Minarrh|015|x} and gather information from the other locals.

{@area Eyes of the Guild.|02f|x} The party delves into the local thieves' guild hideout, where they meet an unexpected ally and discover that Anaya was not kidnapped from the temple, but rather aided in her escape. She fled after being imprisoned in the temple by her father, who is acting strangely. Anaya and her lover Mannan sought refuge with Mannan's aunt, a powerful druid.

{@area The Lovers' Hideaway.|040|x} The party seeks out the druid grove where the lovers have taken refuge. Anaya explains the true story behind the malady and what they must do to defeat the demon who's causing it.

{@area Demonic Confrontation.|04b|x} Accompanied by Anaya and Mannan, the party returns to town in time to witness Tharian absorb the demon into his own body. They must separate the two and slay or banish the demon to save Minnarh and everyone involved.

entries.name: Demon-Caused Malady
entries: The demonic affliction plaguing Minarrh affects young and old alike, seemingly at random. The true cause is simple: the demon imprisoned in an urn within the temple is causing this malady to transform and ultimately consume the life force of the victims and release himself from his confinement. A Humanoid who spends 24 continuous hours in the temple must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or become afflicted.

entries.name: Stages of Malady
entries: The malady progresses through several stages over the course of several days. {@spell Detect Poison and Disease|XPHB|Detect Poison or Disease} reveals that the malady is magical in nature, but doesn't indicate a specific source as the urn is hidden out of the range of the spell.

After {@dice 1d4} days in stage 1, the creature must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or progress to stage 2. Succeed or fail, the afflicted creature must repeat the saving throw each day at dusk, progressing to the next stage of the malady on a failure.
The effects of the malady are cumulative, and {@condition Exhaustion|XPHB} levels caused by this malady aren't removed by finishing a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

items.name: Stage 1
items.entry: A series of painful welts, like the marks of a whip, appear across the afflicted creature's skin.

items.name: Stage 2
items.entry: The afflicted creature suffers from chills, bloodshot eyes, and disorientation. It has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) checks and gains 1 level of {@condition Exhaustion|XPHB}.

items.name: Stage 3
items.entry: The afflicted creature weakens and experiences hallucinations. It gains another {@condition Exhaustion|XPHB} level and has the {@condition Frightened|XPHB} condition when another Humanoid is within 10 feet of it.

items.name: Stage 4
items.entry: The afflicted creature's sclera darken. It has the {@condition Incapacitated|XPHB} condition and gains another {@condition Exhaustion|XPHB} level.

entries: When a creature in stage 4 fails its Constitution saving throw against the progression of the disease, the contents of its skull melt into black ichor, followed by the rest of its body as the creature immediately dies. The ichor temporarily lives on as an ooze (use the {@creature Black Pudding|XMM} stat block), which tries to reach the urn hidden under the temple, where the demon {@creature Xarashtar|MaladyOfMinarrh} is imprisoned. If the ooze doesn't reach the urn quickly, it dissipates into the ground. It only attacks when another creature attacks it or blocks it from reaching the urn.

entries.name: Curing the Malady
entries: All symptoms and conditions of this malady can be temporarily lifted by {@spell Lesser Restoration|XPHB}, but the symptoms return the next time the afflicted creature fails its Constitution saving throw to postpone the progression of the disease. The malady continues unchecked unless cured by {@spell Greater Restoration|XPHB} or similar magic.

entries.name: Adventure Background
entries: Tharian, the temple leader in Minarrh, is in fact under the sway of the demon lord Xarashtar. When Tharian first came to the temple, he discovered an urn and unwittingly formed a pact with the demon, who convinced him that it was his own deity, Damathur, the god of the suffering and afflicted. Through Xarashtar's machinations, Tharian unknowingly brought about the malady by encourging the townspeople to spend more and more time at the temple in prayer, participating in overnight rituals and celebrations of devotion.

Now Xarashtar wields deceit and mind control to corrupt Tharian and sicken his fellow villagers, in order to be released from his prison and gain a hold on the Material Plane, where he plans to establish a reign of suffering and terror.

entries.name: Good Intentions
entries: Tharian is not an evil character—rather, he is a well-intentioned person controlled by an evil being who has convinced him that his actions are for the good of the townspeople. In the final confrontation, the battle for Tharian's soul should clearly be one he is fighting along with all of the characters.

entries.name: Malignant Plans
entries: The malady is much more than a way for the demon lord to torment mortals. For Xarashtar to be released from the urn, Tharian must first ingest a certain amount of the ichorous ooze left behind by those who have fallen to the malady, granting the demon enough power to physically possess the mortal body of Tharian, then destroy the urn so that he can never be imprisoned in it again. When Tharian is reduced to 0 Hit Points or killed, Xarashtar can leave his human host and manifest into his full demonic form.

entries.name: Discovering the Demon
entries: A few months ago, Tharian and his daughter Anaya arrived in Minarrh as missionary healers and joined the local temple. When they moved into their quarters on the temple grounds, Tharian began to hear whispers in his mind as he walked the hallways. The mysterious voice told him of a secret door in the temple, which led to a hidden crypt. There he found an obsidian urn, inlaid with red and gold and marked with strange runes. The voice spoke to Tharian, telling him that it would guide him to cleanse the town of evil and protect the true believers through faithful prayer.

When he laid hands on the urn, the voice grew in power and began to sway him to do more and more acts of "devotion," including bringing the urn from the crypt to a space below the dais in the main sanctum, reciting Abyssal incantations by night, and encouraging the villages to further their devotion by spending more time in the temple.

Through the demon's influence, Tharian convinced most of the local council of elders to meet with him in the temple, bringing them close enough to Xarashtar's urn for the demon to place them under his control through magic similar to a {@spell Mass Suggestion|XPHB} spell. The council gave Tharian full control over the temple's rites and rituals—replacing the role of the elder who refused to attend the meeting—and thus allowing Tharian to further sway the villagers with his fervent sermons and frequent demonstrations of faith.

entries.name: The Daughter and the Demon
entries: Meanwhile, Tharian's daughter Anaya spent more time outside of the temple and became well-known and loved by the townspeople, formed a budding romance with a young druid named Mannan. They kept their relationship secret, believing that Anaya's father—especially as he became more and more insistent on penitence and prayer to Damathur—wouldn't approve of a relationship with someone who worships deities of the forest.

As the first afflicted townspeople came to the temple for help, Anaya noticed her father's erratic behavior, including his resistance to leaving the temple grounds, his commands that the afflicted and their families remain in the temple, and his fanatic insistence that belief and devotion to Damathur is the only solution to the plight of Minarrh.

One night, Anaya found her father late at night in the middle of some kind of fiendish ritual beneath the statue of Damathur in the temple's main sanctum. When he noticed her presence, Tharian, under Xarashtar's control, imprisoned Anaya in her room, as the demon knew that if he could keep her there for more than 24 hours, she would be afflicted by the malady and perish before revealing the truth.

Anaya sent a magical message to Mannan, explaining her plight. Mannan immediately went to the local thieves' guild and promised them a large sum if they would help him free her and secure their passage to his home in the forest, where he lives with his aunt Lysxia, an archdruid who pledged her fealty to a goddess of the forest and is bound to her grove there. The thieves' guild spirited the young lovers away, where Lysxia cured Anaya and hid them within her grove, protected by powerful nature magic.

entries.name: Cast of Characters
entries: The Key Characters table describes the most important characters in the town of Minarrh, along with a pronunciation guide and their pronouns.

entries.caption: Key Characters & Deities
rows: Gifted human healer; Tharian's daughter; Mannan's lover
Human acolyte of the temple of Damathur
God of suffering, healing, and light through the darkness
Goddess of nature, the forest, love and rebirth
Tiefling captain in the local thieves' guild; Rostan's ward
Powerful aasimar druid who protects the land near Minarrh; Mannan's aunt
Human apprentice druid; Anaya's lover; Lysxia's nephew
The innkeeper of the Sunlit Arms, of halfling and orcish descent
Human leader of the temple of Damathur; Anaya's father; controlled by Xarashtar
Demon lord with plans to invade the Material Plane

entries.name: Setting the Adventure
entries: Whether you run this adventure in a published campaign setting or a world of your own, you may adjust the lore as desired to suit your campaign setting. For example, if your game is set in the Forgotten Realms, the god Damathur corresponds to Ilmater and the goddess Inhatrayani corresponds to Sune. In Exandria, Damathur would be an aspect of the Dawnfather and Inhatrayani would be the Wildmother.

entries.name: Adventure Hooks
entries: You can use the following hooks to give the characters a reason to come to Minarrh, or work with your players to create another connection between their characters and the village.

items.name: Call for Aid
items.entry: One of the player characters grew up in Minarrh and received word from a childhood friend or relative that the townspeople are succumbing to an inexplicable malady.

items.name: Rescue and Reward
items.entry: The party learns of a reward of 500 GP promised by a priest named Tharian for the return of his kidnapped daughter.

items.name: Town Under Siege
items.entry: Rumors reach the party that a band of thieves in Minarrh have been responsible for stealing relics and kidnapping the daughter of a highly renowned priest, although no one in the town dares to confront them for their crimes or knows how to find them.

entries.name: A Mysterious Malady
entries: The adventure begins as the characters arrive in Minarrh. Read or paraphrase the following to set the scene:

You've traveled to Minarrh after receiving word of trouble in this small but vibrant town. When you arrive, it's clear that something is amiss: many houses have their windows shuttered or boarded up despite the warm weather, and first few townfolk you see in the streets avert their gaze or back away from you, ducking into alleyways as you pass by. On the main street ahead are a handful of people—some supporting others who struggle to walk, or carrying groaning figures on makeshift stretchers. One of them shouts, "Stay back! We don't know who has it! The temple is the only place to be safe!"

If a character approaches one of the unafflicted townsfolk and makes a successful {@dc 15} Charisma ({@skill Persuasion|XPHB} or {@skill Intimidation|XPHB}) check, the townsperson shares the following information before scurrying away:

items: Their town has been cursed with a terrible malady, and dozens of people have fallen victim to this disease—the first afflicted perished only the other day, but many more are near death.
According to the Minarrhan temple leader, the only way to save their town is through prayer and devotion, which is why so many locals are going to the temple of Damathur with their sick loved ones.

entries: If a character approaches one of the afflicted or their companions, their symptoms (see "{@area Stages of Malady|004|x}" above) are clearly visible, and they refuse to speak until they've reached the temple in the center of town.

entries.name: Temple Under Threat
entries: When the characters approach the temple, read or paraphrase the following:
The temple of Damathur stands tall, its marble and jewel-inlaid columns, floors, and walls glittering in stark contrast to the small and simple buildings throughout the rest of the town.

A temple attendant named Asha (Neutral Good, human {@creature Priest Acolyte|XMM}) is greeting the new arrivals with murmured prayers and reassurances. She ushers the characters inside, explaining that the temple leader is in conducting a prayer ritual but will be free to talk with them when he is done. Asha also tells the characters to stay clear of the makeshift infirmary, the area that has been hastily cordoned off from the main sanctum. She can share the following information if the characters have questions:

items: The temple leader, Tharian, has been desperately trying to help the townspeople cure this malady. He has encouraged everyone not to lose faith and to continue to believe in Damathur's compassion and light.

Ever since Anaya, Tharian's daughter and the town's best healer, was kidnapped by opportunistic thieves, there have been more and more afflicted coming to the infirmary. There are more sick townsfolk than the priests can manage to care for, and more arriving every hour.
The kidnappers must be somehow connected to whatever is happening, but the town is in a panic over the malady and no one has volunteered to seek out and confront them.

entries: As the party enters the temple, read or paraphrase the following:

The large open room is filled with the scent of incense, and as soon as you enter, you are struck by a flurry of activity. To one side of the room, temple clerics tend to ailing patients that they usher into a hallway to the side. On the other, attendees are deep in prayer, repeating the chant of the temple leader, who stands at a dais before them, his expression warm and passionate, yet clearly weary. The interior is crowded with desperate townspeople praying over tokens of their loved ones.
Suddenly, a commotion interrupts the ritual. Read or paraphrase:

As the chant finishes and the priest begins to speak to the crowd, two townspeople run terrified in the main chamber, scratching at their skin and screaming in pain. The temple acolytes attempt to restrain them as their sclera turn black and their eye sockets drip black ichor. As the priest shouts ineffectually for calm, some townsfolk scream and clamber to escape, while others drop to their knees in frantic prayer.

The priest rushes forward, touching one of the afflicted and murmuring a healing spell. The magic fizzles out as the inside of their head dissolves, oozing out of their eye sockets, and then the rest of their body, leaving only a sizzling puddle of black ichor. He pulls back in horror as the ichor slithers toward him, filling the cracks in the stone floor below.

The two oozes ({@creature Black Pudding|XMM|Black Puddings}) from the deceased appear to be moving with purpose toward Tharian (use the {@creature Priest|XMM} stat block) as if to consume him. If an ooze is reduced to half its Hit Point Maximum, or at the end of three rounds of combat, it disappears, soaking through the cracks in the temple floor.

entries.name: A Father's Plea
entries: After the chaos within the temple, Tharian asks to speak with the characters in private. He asks Asha to ensure they are not disturbed in his office as he shares the following:

items: His daughter Anaya is a powerful healer, but she disappeared from her room in the temple two nights ago.

He believes Anaya has been kidnapped by the local thieves' guild, who are trying to use the town's tragedy to leverage a 10,000 GP ransom. (The latter part is not true, although Tharian believes it is—Xarashtar planted the idea of a ransom in his mind to distress him and sow division among the town.)

He can't hope to pay the exorbitant ransom, but he can offer the party 500 GP if they rescue Anaya. Tharian emphasizes Anaya's compassion, selflessness, and role as a beloved member of their community. He's deeply concerned for her safety—and he also worries that without her help, the townspeople will succumb to this terrible malady.

entries: If the party asks for details on the random demands, Tharian explains that he received a message (which he then burned) telling him to drop the money in the old well (see "{@area Eyes of the Guild|02f|x}" below), after which Anaya would be returned safe and sound. With a successful {@dc 15} {@skill Insight|XPHB} check, the characters can tell that while he may seem scattered, Tharian believes this to be the truth.

entries.name: Minarrh Locations
entries: Minarrh is a town steeped in history and tradition, if not a particularly wealthy town, with many houses that have withstood the test of time to shelter multiple generations of Minarrhans. It is clear that religion is the main focus of the town, and theocratic rule has been the tradition for many many years. The party may explore the following key locations in Minarrh as they investigate the cause of the malady.

entries.name: Temple of Damathur
entries: The Temple of Damathur, the largest building in town, is brimming with afflicted townsfolk and worshippers seeking miraculous healing for their loved ones. The temple healers are doing their best to aid those in need.

To search the living quarters ({@area areas 6–11|01d|x}), the party must succeed on a {@dc 15} group Dexterity ({@skill Stealth|XPHB}) check. On a failed check, one of the acolytes finds them and asks them to leave this private area, though they can try again at a later time.

entries.name: 1: Main Sanctum
entries: This large, vaulted chamber is the main hall of the temple, and where the worshipers gather both to pray and to hear the words of their priest when he conducts rituals or shares sermons. The hall is decorated with incense burners, candles, and a variety of relics and art that show the mercy and virtue of Damathur and his worshipers.

entries.name: Statue of Damathur
entries: This marble statue depicts a man in long robes, reaching out with an open palm while the other hand holds a thorny branch. The expression on his face is one of pained compassion, but he stands resolute despite the wounds on his hands and arms. This is Damathur, the god of compassion and endurance, the lord of the afflicted and the suffering.

entries.name: Hidden Urn
entries: A sliding flagstone behind the dais with the statue of Damathur conceals {@creature Xarashtar|MaladyOfMinarrh|Xarashtar's} urn. Finding the groove in the floor requires a successful {@dc 25} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check and activating the hidden mechanism requires a successful {@dc 15} Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand|XPHB}) check.

entries.name: 2: Library
entries: This small library and study area contains tomes on healing arts, potion creation, religion, and other items of devotion. A character who succeeds on a {@dc 20} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check discovers a {@item Spell Scroll|XDMG} of {@spell Banishment|XPHB} tucked away in one of the tomes (see "{@area Demonic Confrontation|04b|x}" later in the adventure).

entries.name: 3: Infirmary
entries: The acolytes tending to the afflicted in the infirmary (including Asha, if she is nearby) do their best to deter the party from entering the infirmary. Within are several afflicted at varying stages of the malady, some with their loved ones tending to them or praying nearby. The acolytes say that no one saw any of the afflicted turn into ooze before the events in the inner sanctum that the characters witnessed. Asha is the only one who, if pressed with a successful {@dc 18} Charisma ({@skill Persuasion|XPHB}) check, can tell the party that she had witnessed one death earlier in the week, but Tharian insisted she not tell anyone lest it create a widespread panic among the townsfolk.

entries.name: 4-5: Closets
entries: These rooms are a storage closet filled with temple paraphernalia and a simple but servicable water closet.

entries.name: 6: Acolytes' Quarters
entries: These simple but comfortable rooms house the temple acolytes.

entries.name: 7: Meditation Garden
entries: The garden contains some slightly overgrown topiary bushes and a reflection pool.

entries.name: 8: Asha's Room
entries: This room belongs to Asha. A tiny cup on the desk holds dried flowers, and book of scriptures lies on the bed.

entries.name: 9: Anaya's Room
entries: Most of this room is clean and organized, but the bed is unmade. A character with a Passive Perception score of 15 or higher, or who succeeds on a {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check, notices a draft from the window, which is slightly open.

entries.name: Anaya's Desk
entries: The desk holds neatly stacked tomes on religion and healing. Pressed between their pages are dried wildflowers and a variety of love letters from Mannan, including one that reads:
My love,

Your fear is too much for me to bear, almost as unbearable as being apart from you. When you are ready to join me, you need only tell me and I will take you from this place, but you must trust me with your life. Learn these symbols, commit them to your heart as you do my name, and I will take you from this darkness that threatens to drain you of your light.
{@link Download Letter|https://raw.githubusercontent.com/TheGiddyLimit/homebrew-img/main/pdf/MaladyOfMinarrh/000-mannan-letter-handout.pdf}

With it, there is also a worn piece of cured animal skin with what seems to be a runic cipher on it, and papers beneath it that she seemed to be practicing this writing on. These runes are a copy of those in the forest near Lysxia's grove (see "{@area The Lovers' Hideaway|040|x}" later in the adventure).

entries.name: 10: Tharians Room
entries: A character who searches Tharian's room with a successful {@dc 20} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check finds a secret, locked compartment in the desk, which requires a successful {@dc 22} Dexterity check using Thieves' Tools to open. It contains scrolls, written in a cryptic version of Abyssal, which describe an ancient rite, but the party cannot decipher more than that.

entries.name: 11: Hallway & Secret Door
entries: At the end of this hallway, an alcove holds a table and small statue. Behind the table is a secret door to the crypt; discovering the door and the hidden opening mechanism requires a successful {@dc 18} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check.

entries.name: 12: Crypt
entries: This dusty crypt contains sarcophagi of previous religious leaders of Minarrh, carved with their likenesses. A character who succeeds on a 18 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check notices an area where the dust has been disturbed and a stone has been removed to reveal a small compartment behind one of the sarcophagi. This is where the urn imprisoning Xarashtar was hidden, until Tharian found it and moved it to the main sanctum upstairs ({@area area 1|017|x}).

Opening any of the sarcophagi requires a successful {@dc 20} Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}) check. Inside, the cremated remains are mostly ash and dust, but some personal effects remain, including a mostly disintegrated journal that contains a sketch of an urn with ornate carvings, as well as a {@item Necklace of Prayer Beads|XDMG}.

entries.name: Sanctum of the Wise
entries: The elders of Minarrh live in the Sanctum of the Wise, the oldest building in the town, once a site of great cultural and religious meaning. When the characters approach, read or paraphrase the following:

Lining the path to the sanctum are weathered stone pillars adorned with intricate carvings, each telling a tale of the village's storied past. Arches frame the entrance, beckoning visitors into the embrace of history and tradition.
Any character from Minnarh knows the following:

items: The elders are revered within the community, known for their wisdom, experience, and deep connection to the town's history and traditions.
The elders are custodians of the village's cultural heritage, entrusted with preserving and passing down ancient rituals, beliefs, and customs.

entries: There are a handful of elders meeting within, who can share the following about Tharian and Anaya:

items: The father and daughter arrived in Minarrh about two months ago, and worked as traveling healers and fellow devotees of Damathur.
As Anaya and Tharian became more beloved and trusted within the town, the temple leaders gave Tharian more freedom to administer rituals and rites within the temple.
After a few weeks, they were so impressed by Tharian's passion and devotion that they asked him to replace the former high priest, Rostan, whom they felt was not strong enough in his faith.
Since Rostan was ousted from his role, the former high priest has not been seen and the other elders believe he has fled the town in shame.

Minarrh is a theocracy, and a character who succeeds on a {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) check gathers that the town isn't generally welcoming to those of different faiths. They are tolerated, but not fully accepted as equals.

entries.name: Fiendish Influence
entries: The town elders are under the sway of the demon, who used magic akin to {@spell Mass Suggestion|XPHB} to keep them from speaking against Tharian. The party can find Rostan hiding out in a small abode by the well that is the entrance to the thieves' guild. (see "{@area Eyes of the Guild|02f|x}" later in the adventure) With a successful {@dc 17} Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) check, a character can tell something seems suspicious but the elders don't seem to be lying or hiding anything. Characters from Minarrh have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on this check.

entries.name: The Sunlit Arms
entries: The only inn in town is surprisingly vacant. When the characters enter, read or paraphrase the following:

When you walk through the main door, you see dirty tables, chairs, and a long bar with a staircase just beyond. In the shadows, a short figure with olive green skin is slumped over the bar, a tankard between their hands and their head hung low. When they register your presence, they look up at you expectantly... then disappointment settles in as they turn back to their drink. "If it's a room you want, they're upstairs. If it's food or supplies, you've come to the wrong place. She's gone and I've lost everything.

Shai, the proprietor of The Sunlit Arms, is about 4 and a half feet tall, with muscular arms, a square jaw, and tiny tusks poking above her downturned lower lip. She tells the party despondently that while the inn's doors are open, she can't offer much in the way of food or comforts. Her partner, Chitani, was the face of the inn while Shai was the cook, but Chitani ran away when she caught the malady, not wanting to burden Shai with watching them suffer... or so Shai believes. In truth, Shai didn't want Chitani to go to the temple, being a staunch unbeliever in the theocratic leadership of the town, and Chitani was claimed by the malady in the night, disappearing when Shai was asleep. Though visitors to the town have been few and far between, Shai has kept the inn doors open in the hopes that Chitani will return.

entries.name: Lovers Meeting
entries: If pressed, Shai can also tell the adventurers that a young man named Mannan had come to the inn a few days ago, before the malady had become fully rampant in the town, and paid Shai double the normal room fee to book a room for two nights but to pay no mind to his comings and goings. Shai noted that the bed remained untouched after his departure.

entries.name: Further Clues
entries: If the party requests a meal, Shai serves them what little fresh food she has left—some simple soup and bread—and if they need basic supplies they can provide dried {@item Rations|XPHB} for their journey. If the party stays the night, one of the rooms they stay in is also where Mannan stayed. A character who searches that room with a successful {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check finds a letter under the floorboards along with a rubbing of a stone-carved map (give the players the {@adventure Thieves' Den Map|MaladyOfMinarrh|0|Thieves Den Map Handout} handout). The letter, which Anaya sent to Mannan before she was imprisoned, reads:
Dearest Mannan,

I fear this darkness that has overtaken my father is more sinister than I imagined. Though I long to come to your side, I fear something terrible may happen should I leave his. I plan to stay awake tonight and keep watch over him to see if I might learn what is plaguing his heart so.
{@link Download Letter|https://raw.githubusercontent.com/TheGiddyLimit/homebrew-img/main/pdf/MaladyOfMinarrh/001-anaya-letter-handout.pdf}

entries.name: Thief In the Night
entries: If the party spends the night in the inn (Shai doesn't ask for money, but if the characters insist on paying tells them the cost is 5 SP per person), a local thief (stat block {@creature Spy|XMM}) pays them a visit.

If no one keeps watch, have one player roll a {@dice d20}. On a 10 or less, when the party wakes up, half of their weapons are gone (along with the map, if the characters haven't yet found it) and a small coin with a symbol of an eye with swirling waves within, left in place of the stolen items.

If a character does keep watch, they can attempt to intercept the intruder, who attempts to flee out the window. If the characters pursue, they can follow the thief to the well (see "{@area Eyes of the Guild|02f|x}" below).

entries.name: Eyes of the Guild
entries: The thieves' guild is a formidable presence within the village and has an eye on everything—hence their moniker "The Eyes." They have been suspicious of the motives of this temple leader as they have watched his fanatical behavior increase over the last few weeks. One of the guild captains, Kynah, is the ward of the elder, Rostan, who is in hiding after being ousted from his position by Tharian and fears retribution should he speak out against him. When they speak to Kynah, the tiefling explains that no kidnapping took place—they actually helped Anaya escape from Minarrh after Tharian imprisoned his daughter in the temple and thus caused her to be afflicted by the malady.
The Eyes operate out of an abandoned well, which the party can discover by speaking with Shai, the the thief at the inn, or Rostan (see "{@area Sanctum of the Wise|026|x}" above).

At the end of this alleyway lies a decrepit old well that clearly hasn't been used in some time. It is covered by moldy wooden planks and the rope and bucket mechanism that would be attached here has long been rotted away. Beside it lies a small sign bearing strange handwritten symbols.

If anyone in the party knows Thieves' Cant, they can read the sign at the base of the well that says "what lies beyond, find friends—or peril." A successful {@dc 16} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check also reveals a hidden door behind the empty well, leading to a small room where Rostan, the single unaffected village elder remains in hiding.

After his initial wariness, he tells the party that he was concerned about the increasing zealousness of the elders toward the temple leader and began to fear for his safety. He came here, a hiding place shown to him by his ward, Kynah, who he describes as "a wayward child who has learned to make their way in the world through unconventional means." Rostan doesn't believe that the thieves' guild kidnapped Anaya—Kynah was treated kindly by Anaya ever since the father and daughter came to Minarrh, despite their very different roles in the town's society. He urges them to speak with her as she is a captain of the Thieves' Guild, which can be entered through the well outside.

With a successful {@dc 18} Charisma ({@skill Persuasion|XPHB}) check—or if the characters simply demonstrate an honest desire to help Anaya—Rostan shares a map with the party showing the pressure plates (a copy of the one they can find in Mannan's room at the {@area Sunlit Arms|029|x}). Give the players the Thieves' Den Map handout.

entries.name: 1: Hideout Entrance
entries: To reach the hideout, the characters must descend into the old well and follow the slimy stone corridor below. The well is 40 feet deep; climbing down unaided requires a successful {@dc 15} Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}) check to descend safely.

You reach the bottom of the old well, stepping into a few inches of muddy, slimy water. Ahead of you, instead of a well wall, you see a hallway. The stony walls of the interior are dimly lit by a small torch but the light isn't enough to see past a few feet before you. Strangely, you hear the dripping of water coming from further ahead, away from where the water source for the well would logically be.

entries.name: 2: Trapped Corridor
entries: The long corridor to the main thieves' guild area is protected by several traps and two {@creature Water Elemental|XMM|Water Elementals} friendly to the guild. There are five pressure plates marked by slightly raised stone tiles on the ground. In order to reach the end of the hallway without setting off the traps, characters must either find and disarm them, or avoid the floor entirely, such as with {@spell Spider Climb|XPHB} or flight.

entries.name: Prepared in Advance
entries: If the party met Rostan and convinced him to give them the map with directions to meet Kynah, or if they have the stone rubbing from Mannan's room at the inn, they have a map of where they need to step to avoid setting off the traps. Within each row of floor tiles that contains a trap, the locations marked with "X" on the map are pressure plates that temporarily disarm that trap; stepping anywhere else within the same row activates the trap. A character who has seen the map and makes a successful {@dc 12} Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) check can piece together that the map matches the shape of this corridor as they enter it.

entries.name: Detect and Disarm
entries: All the traps in this corridor have the same base mechanism to detect and disarm them: as a {@action Search|XPHB} action, a creature within 5 feet of the trapped area can examine it and make a {@dc 18} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check, detecting the trap (the hinge of the trapdoor, holes for the poisoned darts or gas, or grooves in the floor for the well water elementals trap) on a success.

Once the trap is found, a character can take a {@action Study|XPHB} action to examine it and make a {@dc 18} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check, discerning that stepping on a specific pressure plate from the map will allow them to pass without triggering the trap. Stepping on the pressure plate also disarms that trap for 6 seconds.

entries.name: Trap 1: Silent Alarm
entries: {@i Nuisance Trap}

items.name: Trigger:
items.entry: A creature moves onto one of the tiles in the row with pressure plate #1

items.name: Duration:
items.entry: Instantaneous

entries: Stepping on this trap causes a quiet clunking sound, but no other obvious effect. However, it also triggers an alarm in the thieves' meeting room (see "{@area Gathering Room|03d|x}" below) that alerts the guild members in the back room and gives them the jump on the party when they enter the chamber past this hallway.

entries.name: Trap 2: Spiked Pit
entries: {@i Deadly Trap}

items.name: Trigger:
items.entry: A creature moves onto one of the tiles in the row with pressure plate #2

items.name: Duration:
items.entry: Instantaneous

entries: This concealed trapdoor in this section of floor opens into a 10-foot-deep pit filled with sharp spikes. A creature that falls into the pit lands at the bottom and takes 3 ({@dice 1d6}) Bludgeoning damage from the fall plus 9 ({@dice 2d8}) Piercing damage from the spikes. The trapdoor remains open thereafter.

entries.name: Trap 3: Poisoned Darts
entries: {@i Deadly Trap}

items.name: Trigger:
items.entry: A creature moves onto one of the tiles in the row with pressure plate #3

items.name: Duration:
items.entry: Instantaneous, and the trap resets at the start of the next turn if it has activated fewer than three times

entries: Missing the second pressure plate in the sequence triggers a volley of poisoned darts from hidden alcoves in the walls. Each creature in this row of tiles must succeed on a {@dc 14} Dexterity saving throw or be struck by {@dice 1d4} darts, taking 3 ({@dice 1d6}) Poison damage per dart.

entries.name: Trap 4: Poison Gas
entries: {@i Nuisance Trap}

items.name: Trigger:
items.entry: A creature moves onto one of the tiles in the row with pressure plate #4

items.name: Duration:
items.entry: Instantaneous

entries: This mechanism releases a noxious gas, causing damage and potentially poisoning those caught in its cloud.
Disabling the trap involves finding and sealing off the vents or neutralizing the gas source.

entries.name: Trap 5: Well Water Elementals
entries: {@i Deadly Trap}

items.name: Trigger:
items.entry: A creature moves onto one of the tiles in the row with pressure plate #5

items.name: Duration:
items.entry: Instantaneous

entries: If the characters trigger the final trapped floor tile, two walls rise 15 feet apart from each other, blocking off the hallway, and two {@creature Water Elemental|XMM|Water Elementals} seep through the wall from the sides of the corridor and attack the party.
Once the elementals are vanquished, the water in the chamber gradually settles into the floor and the walls blocking the hallway lower, revealing a door ahead.

entries.name: Beyond the Traps
entries: This door is closed, but unlocked (and untrapped). It leads to a simple meeting room where members of the thieves guild, including Kynah, are currently discussing the situation in Minarrh.

If the characters successfully avoided all the traps, the thieves inside are still holding their meeting. With a successful {@dc 12} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check, a character detects muffled voices talking inside the room beyond the door. Otherwise, the thieves have been alerted to the party's presence and are waiting silently, poised to attack as soon as the intruders open the door.

entries.name: 3: Gathering Room
entries: This large meeting room contains a handful of simple tables and stools, devoid of elaborate traps or defenses. At the back of the room stands a sturdy vault, its metal door securely locked and sealed. Four guild members (two {@creature Warrior Veteran|XMM|Warrior Veterans} and two {@creature Spy|XMM|Spies}) are meeting in this room with one of their captains, a {@creature Spy Master|XMM} named Kynah.

entries.name: Encounter with the Guild
entries: The guild does not react well to newcomers and at first, reacts to the party as hostiles—if they have been alerted to the party's presence before their arrival they surprise the party, attacking first and asking questions later. However, upon having a moment to see who they are, a figure orders everyone else to hold their attack. This is Kynah (Chaotic Neutral, tiefling {@creature Spy Master|XMM}), a thieves' guild captain and Rostan's ward. They were present in the crowd but hiding at the prayer ritual at the temple and recognizes the party as the newcomers to town and orders the rest of the guild to pause, holding out a hand in a gesture of peace. Once they are certain the party means them no harm, they reveal their suspicions that there is more behind Anaya's disappearance than there seems.

entries.name: Kynah's Assistance
entries: Kynah was an orphan who arrived in Minarrh as a young girl. Due to her horns, she was met with fear and derision from most of the townspeople. When she met Rostan, he took her under his wing and sheltered her from the wary townsfolk, providing her with shelter, food, and company. She became fond of the old man and he of her, but she remained uncertain that she would ever be accepted by the townspeople. As a teen, she fell in with the thieves' guild, who then took her into their ranks.

During Anaya's time among the Minarrhans, her open attitude and kindness meant that she and Kynah became close friends. Kynah tells the party that the lovers fled the town after Anaya was locked away in the temple and came down with early symptoms of the malady. Mannan contacted Kynah and the lovers escaped the city together under the guild's protection. Kynah is convinced the party must find Anaya and learn the full story of what transpired.

With a successful {@dc 18} Charisma ({@skill Persuasion|XPHB}) check—or if the characters simply demonstrate an honest desire to help Anaya—Kynah offers to aid the party by accompanying them to the area where she escorted the lovers. On a failed check, Kynah simply gives them verbal directions; she warns them to keep their eyes open as the lovers were running to safety with a powerful protector who may not appreciate guests.

Either way, Kynah urges the party to find the lovers. Not only is she worried about her friend's wellbeing, she's also certain that Anaya is the only person who truly knows what is happening in the temple.

entries.name: The Lover's Hideaway
entries: When the characters leave Minarrh, read or paraphrase:

The road out of Minarrh is surrounded by verdant fields, but the longer you travel, the more barren they become. A large stone outcropping marks a stark change in landscape—where greenery once grew, you now see slates of rock covered in slippery, foul-smelling moss. The pleasant breeze that has accompanied you since Minarrh now carries a mildewed, pungent odor. The cracked ground holds no evidence of travelers, no footsteps or trail, only barren, jagged rocks.

If Kynah is guiding the party, they reach the entrance to the grove easily and without incident, and Kynah tells them not to believe what their eyes see of the terrain. Otherwise, they can follow Kynah's directions with a successful {@dc 13} Wisdom ({@skill Survival|XPHB}) check. On a failure, they gain a level of {@condition Exhaustion|XPHB} before reaching the grove.

entries.name: Approaching the Grove
entries: In fact, the archdruid who is protecting the lovers has cast {@spell Mirage Arcane|XPHB} in this area, turning the verdant landscape within half a mile of the hideaway into rocky outcroppings covered in slippery, foul-smelling fungus and moss. This is {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB}.
A creature who travels in this area must succeed on a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw or have the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition for 1 hour.

entries.name: Runic Riddle
entries: A character with a Passive Perception score of 15 or higher, or a character who succeeds on a {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check in this area, notices the runes on rocks and trees. A character who read the letter from Mannan in Anaya's room (see "{@area Temple of Damathur|016|x}" earlier in the adventure) has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on this check.

You notice runes etched into the stones and barren trees. While there is no sound other than your footsteps and the gentle, foul-smelling breeze, it is clear this area is not untrodden—it's clearly inhabited by something or someone, and they have left their mark to make it known. The land pulses with something strange, as if alive with energy or magic.
Ahead lies another large, rune-inscribed stone, standing tall and tilted at an unnatural angle as if by design. Beyond it is a thick layer of fog, completely obscuring the path ahead.
Characters who know Druidic can read the following message carved into the rock:

This sacred land knows no faith but love The word to pass true friends should know of The language of light, speaks loving and true Can we trust the same of you? Through treacherous paths we find our way If true love's nature we know to say.
Below in Common, is written:
Speak aloud: What is the nature of love?

With a Passive Insight score of 20, or a successful {@dc 20} Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) or Intelligence ({@skill Religion|XPHB}) check, a character can discern that an offering should be made to the deity of this land. For each appropriate offering or prayer the characters make, two random letters appear in the blank spaces. The answer is ETERNAL. The party need not solve this riddle to move forward, but it will make the challenges ahead easier.

A series of obstacles cover the ground ahead (see the {@adventure Lovers' Hideaway map|MaladyOfMinarrh|0|Map: The Lovers' Hideaway}). Each character who has spoken the correct password in answer to the riddle is immune to the effects described below.

items.name: Solid Fog
items.entry: A 10-foot-high layer of fog fills this entire area, making it {@variantrule Lightly Obscured|XPHB}. In addition, every foot of movement through the fog costs 2 extra feet. To a creature immune to this effect, the fog obscures nothing and looks like soft mist, with motes of green light floating in the air.

items.name: Grasping Undergrowth
items.entry: This 30-foot-by-90-foot area is filled with grasping weeds and vines, as with the {@spell Entangle|XPHB} spell. To a creature immune to this effect, the weeds and vines feel soft and reshape themselves to serve as temporary seats or beds.

items.name: Spike Growth
items.entry: This 30-foot-by-90-foot area is {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB}. When a creature moves into or within the area, it takes {@damage 2d4} piercing damage for every 5 feet it travels. For a creature immune to this effect, the thorns move aside to allow their passage.

entries: Within the area are also four giant, leafless trees (any character with proficiency in the {@skill Nature|XPHB} skill knows that it's strange for trees to be leafless this time of year.)

entries.name: Lysxia's Grove
entries: When the characters come within 40 feet of the entrance, a voice calls out in warning:
"Strangers, come no further unless you speak the word of passing! If you do not heed me, these steps may be your last."

A tall figure steps forward, wearing a flowing long skirt and a blouse that comes to her waist. She is wreathed in leaves and flowers, with vines intertwining to form lush jewelry, and her skin glows with a coppery reflection that is a perfect complement to her warm golden eyes. As she approaches, four trees in this clearing sway despite no discernible breeze. She speaks warmly, calmly, and firmly.
"I have no quarrel with you, but nature itself protects its faithful, its children—and there is nothing more natural than love."
This is Lysxia, a Neutral, aasimar {@creature Archdruid|MPMM}.
If the party attacks, the four {@creature Awakened Tree|XMM|Awakened Trees} move to protect Lysxia, and she warns the characters to to stand down.

If the characters explain why they've come to the grove, either with the "word of passing" (the answer to the above riddle) or a successful {@dc 18} Charisma ({@skill Persuasion|XPHB}) check, the obstacles in the area subside and Lysxia calls to the young druid, Mannan. Reticent and defensive though he may be, upon talking to him they discover he fled with the temple leader's daughter, Anaya and they have been hiding with the help of this powerful druid, who is also Mannan's aunt. She is a devotee of Inhatrayani, the goddess of nature and love, and Lysxia doesn't subscribe to the more organized and exclusive religion as practiced by the followers of Damathur. She is apathetic to their plight, believing that their holiness is hypocritical, knowing how they treat others of different faiths and backgrounds.

entries.name: Anaya's Story
entries: Anaya tearfully recounts her story to the party, revealing her falling out with her father as she discovered he was being controlled by some evil being. She had seen signs of his strange behavior, muttering to himself under his breath, snapping at her in ways that didn't make sense, not sleeping and speaking more obsessively about their deity and the absolution they were going to visit upon Minarrh. When Anaya followed her father one night as he retrieved the demonic vessel underneath the dais in the temple sanctum and discovered him filling it with the ichorous ooze left behind by one of the afflicted, he caught her and imprisoned her in her quarters. After 24 hours, she began to show symptoms of the malady and cast {@spell Sending|XPHB} to Mannan. He immediately sought out Kynah and made a bargain with her to quickly and in dark of night get Anaya to his aunt Lysxia, who cast {@spell Greater Restoration|XPHB} on her and cured her of the malady, then offered asylum from any who should come to hunt them.

As Lysxia is bound to the grove she protects she cannot go to the town to help in their healing (and is not inclined to based on their unaccepting traditions). Anaya entreats the party to assist her in saving her father from the thrall of the demon.

entries.name: Making Plans
entries: Anaya is desperate to help save her father and wants to return to Minarrh with the party, which Mannan will not let her do alone. Anaya suggests that if the party can enable her to get close enough to him to touch him, she can cast {@spell Dispel Evil and Good|XPHB|Dispel Evil} on him to break whatever enchantment has a hold on him and hopefully when she does they can defeat whatever force has been controlling him. She cannot be thwarted from her goal to save her father.
Unfortunately Lysxia is bound to the land as its protector, but she sends the lovers back with several magic items for their protection and to help the party.

At your discretion as DM, Lysxia can offer a few of the following items to the party: a {@item Mace of Disruption|XDMG}, a {@item Mantle of Spell Resistance|XDMG}, a {@item Necklace of Prayer Beads|XDMG}, a {@item Ring of Invisibility|XDMG}, a {@item Spell Scroll|XDMG} of {@spell Protection from Evil and Good|XPHB|Protection From Good and Evil}, a {@item Spell Scroll|XDMG} of {@spell Mass Cure Wounds|XPHB}, and a {@item Spell Scroll|XDMG} of {@spell Dispel Evil and Good|XPHB}.

The characters can take a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB} here. Anaya is concerned for the fate of the townspeople and her father, but counsels the party that they'll need all their strength to fight the demon controlling him.

entries.name: Demonic Confrontation
entries: When the characters return to Minarrh, they find the town smelling faintly of rot and mold, with no townspeople in sight. They also see a faint reddish glow emanating from the temple entrance. If she was with the party, Kynah leaves their side to seek out Rostan and make sure he is safe.

The party encounters Asha, the young acolyte, running from the temple in fear and seeing her covered in welts as she too has been afflicted. She tells the adventurers that Tharian has gone mad, the elders have disappeared, and she fears the whole town will fall if he is not confronted.

entries.name: Return to the Temple
entries: When the characters reach the temple, read or paraphrase the following:

Where the clean marble once stood, there are black, dripping veins within the stone. A faint stench of brimstone fills the air, and a shadowed silhouette of a man stands just inside the temple's opening. Anaya moves as if to rush forward, but Mannan holds her back as Tharian holds a large obsidian urn with shimmering red and gold carvings up to his lips. Black ichor dribbles out of the urn into his mouth and down the sides of his face.

Tharian stands taller than before, his shoulders broadened and his once-warm brown eyes darkened. He reaches forward toward you, long claw-like nails protruding from his fingertips as his mouth curves into an inhuman grin.

"You have returned with my beloved daughter, as you promised. And now, as I promised, I will deliver you the reward you have so rightly earned. Come forth and receive the blessing of your new lord, the great Xarashtar, through whom all life is cleansed and reborn."
Tharian is almost fully possessed by the demon lord Xarashtar (see "{@area Fighting Tharian|04f|x}" below). He now uses the {@creature Fiend Cultist|XMM} stat block with the following adjustments:

items: He has no Breastplate; his AC is 12.
He has Resistance to Necrotic and Poison damage.
His attacks and spells that deal Fire damage instead deal Necrotic or Poison damage (his choice).

entries.name: Anaya and Mannan
entries: Anaya's sole focus during the encounter is to end her father's possession by the demon by using the Break Enchantment function of {@spell Dispel Evil and Good|XPHB}. Because Anaya must touch him to end the possession, she aims to get herself as close to her father as possible and continues to plead with him to fight the demon's control. Anaya uses the {@creature Priest|XMM} stat block with the following adjustments:

items: She has no Chain Shirt or Mace, but her Dexterity score is 16 (+3), giving her AC 13 and Initiative +3 (13).
In addition to the spells in her stat block, she can cast {@spell Dispel Evil and Good|XPHB} (1/Day) and {@spell Sending|XPHB} (1/ Day) with her Spellcasting action.
She has {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to the {@condition Charmed|XPHB} and {@condition Frightened|XPHB} conditions.

entries: Mannan uses the {@creature Druid|XMM} stat block. He focuses solely on protecting Anaya. If she falls in battle he immediately changes his focus to carry her to safety.

entries.name: Fighting Tharian
entries: Xarashtar targets Anaya first and foremost, believing her to be the biggest threat against him. But as he does, Tharian continues to fight the possession as he's finally confronted with the horror of what his actions have wrought.

At the start of each of Tharian's turns, he makes a {@dc 20} Wisdom saving throw. He has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on this saving throw as long as Anaya is present and not {@condition Incapacitated|XPHB}. On a failure, Xarashtar maintains control of Tharian's body and continues to fight the party, Anaya, and Mannan. On a success, Tharian can move and speak normally until the end of his turn, but can't take other actions. He speaks to Anaya and the party, telling them they can banish the demon if they find a {@item Spell Scroll|XDMG} of {@spell Banishment|XPHB} in the temple library (see "{@area Temple of Damathur|016|x}" earlier in the adventure).

entries.name: Demonic Transformation
entries: If Tharian is reduced to 0 Hit Points or if Anaya succeeds at dispelling evil, the demon exits his body and manifests in his true form, a {@creature Glabrezu|XMM}. In addition to the spells in his stat block, Xarashtar can also cast {@spell Mass Suggestion|XPHB} (1/Day) with his Spellcasting action.
When Xarashtar appears, read or paraphrase:

Tharian's frail body slumps to the ground, unconscious. Anaya runs toward him, then suddenly stops dead in her tracks as a stream of ichor and smoke streams from upward from Tharian's unmoving form. It grows in size and shape, like a bulbous, oozing cloud, revealing portions of a form within—first, one pair of massive arms ending in giant pincers, and below that a pair of smaller, muscular humanoid hands, balled into powerful fists.

As the ichor drips away and the smoke clears, you see a monstrous creature standing 15 feet tall, a canine, fanged head with two jagged horns protruding from its crown. It gestures to Tharian's body lying at at its clawed feet.

"Sad puny human. I knew this withered shell would not serve me long... but long enough to bring me forth to this realm." It grabs the obsidian urn that Tharian had been drinking from and throws it to the ground, shattering it into pieces. "I, Xarashtar, lay claim to this place, this town, this land and soon my minions will feast as I have on your mortal souls."

entries.name: Fighting Xarashtar
entries: The party can defeat the demon either by casting Banishment upon him or reducing him to 0 Hit Points, thereby banishing him back to his plane of existence.

If the players come up with other ways to defeat or re-imprison Xarashtar, use your discretion as GM to determine the effectiveness of those methods and reward player creativity. Similarly, if Anaya is still under the effects of {@spell Dispel Evil and Good|XPHB}, she may be able to use the Dismissal function of the spell to banish Xarashtar; if this is a possibility, take care to ensure that the player characters aren't upstaged and it is their actions that ultimately lead to the demon lord's defeat.
When the demon is defeated, read or paraphrase:

As Xarashtar's massive form disappears, returning him to the Abyss, the veins of ichor that seemed to have permeated the walls grow fainter and fainter, until they dissipate altogether, the corruption draining from the hallowed hall. Even the air feels like it is lighter, and the smell of brimstone gives way to the more familiar smells of incense and the foliage of the nearby garden.

entries.name: Concluding the Adventure
entries: When Tharian is revived, he is filled with shame, regret, and gratitude for all the party has done.

As Anaya and Mannan lift her fallen father to his feet, he addresses the party—his head low in weakness and shame. "I have no words to even begin to thank you for what you have done. You have saved not only our town but my very soul from everlasting damnation. I don't know how the people of this town can ever forgive me, or how I can forgive myself... but that is less important than the debt of gratitude I owe to you all."

"I will relinquish all authority I have in this holy place, which should never have been given to me, and return it to the hands of the elders and acolytes who can hopefully mend not only the damage to this temple but to the hearts of the followers who worship here. But as I do, I will make sure that you are rewarded for your bravery and tenacity in the face of such evil."

Tharian thanks Mannan and begs forgiveness from him and Anaya. He asks Mannan to convey his thanks to Lysxia, and to request that she allow them to bring the remaining afflicted to her grove for healing. Mannan agrees, and says he'll do his best to convince her to work with the townsfolk so long as they all promise to stay open to worshipers of all kinds, not just followers of their deity. Tharian agrees, gives his blessing to the lovers, and gives the party a reward of 1,000 GP. In addition, the party might receive the following items:

items: {@item Necklace of Prayer Beads|XDMG|Inhatrayani's Necklace of Prayer Beads} from Lysxia and Mannan (or another magic item suggested in the "{@area Making Plans|04a|x}" section earlier in the adventure)
Tokens of friendship from Kynah or Anaya, if the party befriended them.

entries: To bring the adventure to a close, read or paraphrase:

In the days that follow, you rest and tend to your wounds, and Anaya and Mannan quickly go to work—with the help of Kynah and her fellow guild members—shuttling afflicted townsfolk out to the forest grove and to the healing hands of Lysxia. Tharian, still overwhelmed with remorse, convalesces and grows stronger, and Rostan reclaims the duties of temple priest. When Tharian recovers, he and Anaya continue their healing work in the town, now aided by Mannan, who Rostan also invites to share the teachings of his goddess to the Minarrhans, to show that despite their difference of faiths the core beliefs of love, forgiveness, and redemption are the same.
Together Anaya, Mannan, Tharian, the elders, and the rest of Minarrh heal and rebuild—and the characters prepare themselves for their next adventure.
